content.text: The thermometer in Fig. 1.2 shows room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) at the beginning of the experiment. Record \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\)
\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\)   .........  \(^\circ \mathrm{C}\)
Suggest two precautions that you would take to obtain an accurate value for the highest temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{M}}\) of the mixture
Calculate the decrease in temperature \(\Delta \theta_{1}\) of the hot water using the equation \(\Delta \theta_{1} = (\theta_{\mathrm{H}} - \theta_{\mathrm{M}})\). Include the unit
Calculate the increase in temperature \(\Delta \theta_{2}\) of the cold water using the equation \(\Delta \theta_{2} = (\theta_{\mathrm{M}} - \theta_{\mathrm{C}})\). Include the unit
The student records the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{C}}\) of a supply of cold water
She records the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}}\) of a supply of hot water
She immediately pours \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of the hot water into a beaker containing \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of the cold water. She records the highest temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{M}}\) of the mixture
Calculate the average \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}}\) of the temperatures \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}}\) and \(\theta_{\mathrm{C}}\). Show your working. Include the unit
State whether \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}}\) and \(\theta_{\mathrm{M}}\) can be considered to be equal within the limits of experimental accuracy. Justify your answer by reference to the results
statement
justification
State two requirements when reading the volume of water in a measuring cylinder to obtain an accurate result
A student investigates temperature changes when mixing hot and cold water
Fig. 1.1 shows the set-up

Line \(\mathbf{MR}\) shows the position of the plane mirror. Draw a normal to this line that passes through its centre. Label the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\). Label the point at which \(\mathbf{NL}\) crosses \(\mathbf{MR}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{B}\)

Draw a line 7.0 cm long from \(\mathbf{B}\) at an angle of incidence \(\alpha = 30^{\circ}\) to the normal below \(\mathbf{MR}\) and to the left of the normal. Label the end of this line \(\mathbf{A}\)
Suggest a suitable distance apart for pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) for this type of ray-trace experiment
distance =   .........
State the reason for your suggested distance
The student places the reflecting face of the mirror vertically on the line \(\mathbf{MR}\)
• He places two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\), on line \(\mathbf{AB}\) at a suitable distance apart for this type of ray-trace experiment
Measure, and record in Table 2.1, the acute angle \(\beta\) between the line through the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) and the line \(\mathbf{MR}\)
Add units to the column headings in Table 2.1
The student views the images of pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 2.1

• He places two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_2\) and \(\mathsf{P}_1\) all appear exactly one behind the other. The positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) are marked on Fig. 2.1
Draw a line through the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\). Continue the line until it meets \(\mathbf{MR}\)
The student places the reflecting face of the mirror vertically on the line \(\mathbf{MR}\) with the centre of the mirror at \(\mathbf{B}\)
He repeats the procedure using an angle of incidence \(\alpha = 45^{\circ}\). The values of \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) are recorded in Table 2.1
Calculate, and record in Table 2.1, the values of \((\alpha + \beta)\)
Suggest a relationship, if any, between the two values of \((\alpha + \beta)\) in Table 2.1
In order to investigate further a possible relationship between values of \((\alpha + \beta)\), more values are required
Suggest values of the angle of incidence \(\alpha\) that the student could use
The student does this experiment with care
Suggest a practical reason why the results may not be exactly those that the theory of reflection predicts
A student investigates the position of the image in a plane mirror
Fig. 2.1 shows the ray-trace sheet
\(\leftarrow\) eye
The student places the metre rule on the pivot so that the metre rule is as near as possible to being balanced. Fig. 3.2 shows the position of the pivot
Record the scale reading \(S\) on the metre rule at the point where the rule balances on the pivot
The metre rule is \(4 \text{mm}\) thick. The pivot is under the metre rule. The scale is on the top of the metre rule. Suggest how you would obtain an accurate value of the scale reading \(S\)
• The student places an object Q with its centre on the metre rule at the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark. The position of Q is not changed during the experiment
• He places a load P of weight \(P = 1.0 \text{N}\) on the metre rule
• He adjusts the position of load P so that the metre rule is as near as possible to being balanced with the pivot directly below the scale reading S
• He records, in Table 3.1, the distance \(a\) from the centre of load P to the centre of load Q
• He repeats the procedure using loads of weight \(P = 2.0 \text{N}, 3.0 \text{N}, 4.0 \text{N}\) and \(5.0 \text{N}\)
• He records all the values of \(a\) in Table 3.1
Complete the column headings in Table 3.1 by inserting the unit in the \(\frac{1}{P}\) column
Plot a graph of \(a / \text{cm}\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(\frac{1}{P}\) (\(x\)-axis). Start the \(y\)-axis at \(a / \text{cm} = 30\)
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
The gradient \(G\) is numerically equal to the distance \(d\) between the pivot and the centre of load Q. Record the value of \(d\) to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment
A student investigates the balancing of a metre rule
Fig. 3.1 shows the set-up

A student investigates the effect on the resistance of a wire when the tension in the wire is increased. The apparatus is shown in Fig. 4.1. The tension in the wire is increased by adding loads to the hook attached to the wire. The student measures the current \(I\) in the wire and the potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) across the wire. She determines the resistance \(R\) of the wire using the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)
The student takes all the necessary safety precautions. You are **not** required to write about safety precautions
The following apparatus is available:
· resistance wire
· power source, connecting wires and crocodile clips
· ammeter
· voltmeter
· selection of loads and a hanger
